Award.AbstractNarration:
This award will fund a 5-day conference to be held during the spring of 2016 at the University of Texas Rio Grande Valley on the topic of discrete Painlevé equations. The main lecturer will be Professor Nalini Joshi of the University of Sydney, Australia. The study of Painlevé equations is closely related to integrable systems and can be useful in the modeling of applications from atmospheric circulation to thermal properties of metals. This conference will focus in particular on functions that are solutions of nonlinear recurrence relations, called the discrete Painlevé equations. The search for these equations and study of their solutions has become a major focus of research over the past two decades. However, very little is known about their general solutions, primarily because mathematical tools are not available. The lectures will provide information for mathematicians and scientists who may encounter the discrete Painlevé equations as models in the course of their research and introduce mathematical tools for identifying and describing solutions of nonlinear non-autonomous difference equations. The conference will bring Dr. Joshi, a world-expert, to a Hispanic-serving Institution, introducing new developments in the field to a diverse group of students, postdoctoral researchers, and faculty.

The conference speakers will describe the properties of discrete Painlevé equations and discuss tremendous new research developments in the field. The main lectures and the supplemental lectures plan to address the following major themes: (1) the basic theory of nonlinear difference equations; (2) the connection between discrete integrable systems and continuous integrable systems; (3) the connection of geometry with discrete Painlevé equations, especially the ell-discrete Painlevé equation; (4) asymptotic analysis of discrete Painlevé equations; and (5) obtaining special solutions through elementary methods such as Hirota's bilinear form and Bäcklund and other transformations. This conference is jointly supported by the Infrastructure Program and the Analysis Program in the NSF Division of Mathematical Sciences.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Overview: Professor Nalini Joshi, Georgina Sweet Australian Laureate Fellow in mathematics and the Chair of Applied Mathematics at the University of Sydney, has served as the Principal Lecturer of the conference and delivered ten lectures as a self–contained and comprehensive exposition on the new and modern developments in the subject of discrete Painlevé equations.

Intellectual Merit: The general area of the conference’s endeavor is of great scientific interest and has seen an explosive expansion of research activity in the last few years, both in modern mathematical theory and in diverse applications, including nonlinear waves, energy levels of heavy particles in atomic physics, and thermal properties of metals, just to name a few. The research focus included three general aspects encountered in the theory of discrete Painlevé equations: (i) the connection between discrete and continuous Painlevé equations (ii) the asymptotic analysis of discrete Painlevé equations and (iii) obtaining special solutions through elementary methods such as Hirota’s bilinear form, Backlund and other transformations. Despite efforts in this area, there are still many new developments which are only coming within the range of modern theory and applications. 

Broader Impact: The conference stimulated the interest in research, teaching and learning of graduate students and faculty of mathematics, science and engineering at many institutions in the region, and in particular at The University of Texas Rio Grande Valley. The conference brought together a group of experts and researchers to share their ideas, methods, and perspectives on the subject for further developments of advanced study and research. The conference attracted junior researchers, graduate and postdoctoral students including women, and individuals from underrepresented groups. 

Major scientific activities:

* Pre-­conference presentation by Prof. Nalini Joshi on the topic of women in the sciences
* Ten lectures by Professor Nalini Joshi of the University of Sydney, Australia as the Principal Lecturer
  1. Introduction to Nonlinear Difference Equations
  2. Review of Integrable Systems
  3. Key Properties of the Painleve? Equations
  4. Discrete Integrable Equations from Continuous Integrable Equations
  5. Discrete Painleve? Equations, an Overview
  6. Discrete Painleve? Equations, a More Detailed View
  7. Discrete Painleve? Equations through Geometry
  8. Affine Weyl Groups and Discrete Painleve? Equations
  9. Discrete Isomonodromy Problems
  10. Asymptotics
* Invited talks by three other leading experts:
  1. Geometric Aspects of Painleve? Equations: A Brief Introduction (Kenji Kajiwara, Kyushu University, Japan) 
  2. The (Noncommutative) Geometry of Differential and Difference Equations (Eric Rains, California Institute of Technology, USA)
  3. Algebraic Entropy, a Primer (Claude M. Viallet, Sorbonne Universite?, UPMC, France)

* Seven short presentations and six poster presentations

* Daily informal discussion session for five days

* Post-­conference presentations

  1. Vladimir Dragovic (University of Texas at Dallas) "Poncelet polygons, the Painlevé VI and the Schlesinger equations."
  2. Francois Leyvraz (National University of Mexico) "Isochronous Hamiltonians, their Quantisation and their Possible Significance in Statistical Mechanics"
